The Real Leadership Lesson of Steve Jobs

Six months after Jobs's death, the author of his best-selling biography identifies the practice that every CEO can try to by Walter lsaacson

His sage is the entrepreneurial creation myth writ large: Steve Jobs confonded Apple in his parents' garage in 1997, was ousted in 1985, returned to rescue it from near bankruptcy in 1997, and by the time he died, in october 2011, had built it into the world's most valuable company. Along the way he helped to tarnsform seven industries: personal computing, animated movies, music, phone, tablet computing, retail stores, and digital publishing. He thus belongs in the pantheon of Amarica's great innovators, along with Thomas Edison, Henry Ford, and Walt Disney. None of these men was a saint, but long after their personalities are forgotten, history will remember how they applied imagination to technology and business.
